awd_titl_txt: Experiencing Science Practices through Research to Inspire Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
The Noyce Program at the University of Oregon is a collaboration among the University of Oregon-Eugene's College of Education and College of Arts and Sciences, Eugene 4J School District, Springfield School District, Bethel School District, and Creswell School District. Over 5 years, the project will produce 20 new teachers who have STEM baccalaureate degrees and are prepared to teach in high-need school districts.  The project will first recruit high-achieving sophomore or junior students who are majoring in STEM disciplines; these students will become Noyce interns.  All Interns will participate in a sponsored 10-week summer program involving original research under the guidance of a mentoring team consisting of research scientists, a master secondary science teacher with research experience, and a science educator from the Experiencing Science Practices through Research to Inspire Teaching (ESPRIT) team.  In addition, these Noyce interns will be engaged in course work in promoting equity and diversity in schools, rigorous science coursework, teacher community-building activities, and an on-going "Noyce seminar" focused on integrating these experiences. In their senior year and post-baccalaureate year, Noyce Scholars will experience extensive supervised field work in high-need school districts and graduate with a master's degree, an initial Oregon teaching license (through UOTeach) and an ESOL (English for speakers of other languages) endorsement. In the process, the project will add to the production of University of Oregon (UO) science teachers, nominally doubling the annual production and tripling UO homegrown science teachers. 

Individuals who are recruited and prepared through the Noyce Program will be uniquely qualified to take leadership roles in high-need schools serving groups that are typically underrepresented in STEM fields, especially English language learners. With their background in scientific research, science teaching preparation, and ESOL training, Noyce alumni will have the skills and resources to realize the vision of the Next Generation Science Standards, including engaging their students in authentic practices of scientists augmented by an emphasis on social justice. Consequently, these Noyce Scholars will have the potential to assist in the recruitment of the next generation of scientists in Oregon. The project's PIs will systematically study the impact of program activities on the recruitment, retention and teaching effectiveness of the Noyce Scholars. A primary goal is to inform the research on preparing teachers to engage students in science inquiry in high-need schools. For example, the teacher research experience coupled with acquisition of ESOL pedagogical skills prepares the Noyce Scholars to model the practices of scientists in high-need schools in a potentially transformative program.

por.por_cntn:
The ESPRIT (Experiencing Science Practices through Research to Inspire Teaching) Noyce Track 1 project was designed to strengthen and diversify secondary science instruction by recruiting and preparing teaching candidates with undergraduate science degrees and extensive research experience. Ultimately, these teachers will elevate science instruction for all students and improve student access to scientific careers. 

 ESPRIT provided $10K scholarships for 14 University of Oregon (UO) Senior Scholars and supported 23 total UOTeach Graduate Scholars with $22K scholarships.  All participants completed the UOTeach program having achieved a master’s degree, teacher licensure, and English for Speakers of Other Language (ESOL) certification.  

 Thirty-three undergraduate science major ESPRIT Interns undertook an 8-week summer research experience in either a UO science lab (31) or as part of the STAR (STEM Teacher and Researcher Program) program (2).  The summer researchers attended two ESPRIT seminars, one led by a scientist focusing on science communications, with students producing a 3-minute research talk, ‘research action photos,’ and a research poster.  The other was led by an expert secondary science teacher emphasizing connections to Next Generation Science Standards and producing a science research-focused ‘teaching nugget’ for use in future classrooms.  These summer experiences helped 14 participants decide on a career in teaching and apply for an ESPRIT senior year scholarship.

 During their senior year these 14 science majors, spanning 5 cohorts, enrolled in equal opportunity education courses focused on equity, access and inclusion and counting towards their UOTeach coursework. The UOTeach program emphasizes the importance of providing opportunities for all K-12 students to explore careers as scientists. Nine science bachelor’s degree attainers with significant science research experience joined the fourteen while enrolled in UOTeach as Graduate Scholars.  An annual ‘signing ceremony’ was held for each cohort of Scholars, beginning with a science research poster session. College of Arts and Sciences and College of Education deans attended, praising each Noyce Scholar graduating from UOTeach.  ESPRIT also recruited expert teachers to mentor graduated Scholars during their first year of teaching.

 Evaluation of the ESPRIT project comprised all Interns completing the ESPRIT Pre-Survey and then annually completing the ESPRIT Post-Survey and Card-Sort Activity along with additional surveys if an ESPRIT Senior Scholar, ESPRIT Graduate Scholar, or former ESPRIT Scholar/ESPRIT Teacher. Additionally, all participants were interviewed at the end of the summer (if an ESPRIT Intern) or at the end of the academic year (if an ESPRIT Scholar, ESPRIT Graduate Scholar, or ESPRIT Former Scholar). The ESPRIT Post-Survey included three highly-cited scales. 

Aside from the scholarship money, the biggest impact from participating in the ESPRIT program for many science teachers was the ESPRIT support and mentorship, the professional development offered to them, and the community of Scholars they created. For example, one stated “I don't know of any other scholarship program that offers so many good professional development opportunities. These have been truly wonderful. I also really value the connections I have made through the ESPRIT program - having a ‘teaching family’ of support is vital to the longevity of a teaching career, I am finding.”  

Interviews with other ESPRIT teachers emphasized the importance of the summer research experience coupled with the two concurrent seminars: “I believe that people who have participated in the ESPRIT program are prepared differently than other teachers going through the UOTeach program because they have research experience. I think that this gives the teachers a better idea of what science is about and how real scientific research is different from what has traditionally been done in a classroom. I think that having a background in research is beneficial to science teachers because there is a mindset you gain (as well as skills and knowledge). The mindset is that you don't have to know everything. It is okay to learn alongside your students and I think science becomes more engaging that way. I see more engagement from my students when we are all learning something together,” and:  “Research gave me a leg up – ESPRIT altogether did this – so by the time I was in UOTeach I already had way more background knowledge than my peers. My understanding of NGSS was really strong because of Lisa’s class (the summer Research into Teaching Seminar) and my research experience is something I reference a lot and is meaningful for [my students]. I show them pictures of my friends who have done research in science as part of ESPRIT. It gives them different ideas of what a scientist is. My students have not been exposed to much science so I show them how any interest intersects STEM, how scientists can look, how science is about questions... It gave me a stronger sense of purpose to teach it well and to rural students and those marginalized in science.”
